data.sub:
[{"id":10905,"main_id":61264,"questions":1,"subject":"Who is going to get married?","answer":"B. Bob.","answer_a":"A. Jack.","answer_b":"B. Bob.","answer_c":"C. Kate.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Hello.

M: Kate? It’s Jack.

W: Hi, Jack. How are you? 

M: Great. I was wondering. Would you like to go to the shopping center with me? I need to get some clothes for a wedding.

W: Sounds good. Who’s getting married?

M: My friend Bob. I need to get a new suit and tie.

W: I’ve never seen you wear a tie.

M: Well, I don’t very often, but it’s a wedding.

W: OK. What time?

M: Can we go there now? After that we can have lunch nearby.

W: Great.

M: My friend Bob. I need to get a new suit and tie.

W: I’ve never seen you wear a tie.

W: Great.

M: Do you like musicals, Mary? I went to see Cats three times when it played in Tokyo.

W: Yeah, it’s really fantastic. I have seen it once.

M: By the way, what shows are playing now on Broadway? If there’s a good one, I’d like to get two tickets in advance.

W: The Producers is on. Getting tickets can be difficult. You can get them on the Internet, but I am not sure you can get the date you want.

M: OK, I’ll try my best. Mary, the hotel we are going to stay in is the Hotel Ritz. 

W: Really? In fact, I’ve never been to New York. Could I hire you as my guide?

M: With pleasure.

W: Now, Matt, what are you interested in doing in the future?

M: I’m especially interested in things related to television.

W: Are you interested in acting?

M: No, I’m more interested in doing something connected with real-life events and news. I see myself more as somebody who works behind the scenes, like a producer.

W: What would you say your personal strengths are? Are you good at organizing and working on a team, for example?

M: Yes, I’d say so. I’ve been the captain of the basketball team for the last three years, and I’ve recently helped to produce a short play at school.

W: And besides playing sports and doing plays?

M: I help to edit the school magazine, and I write information for the school website.

M: Oh, how much? I don’t want to spend more than $500.

W: Well, this model costs $750 in the city, but our special tax-free price is $599. 

M: Well. Can you tell me more about it? I haven’t heard of this brand.

M: Yes, it’s great. I like the rounded corners. 

W: And it’s well worth the money. I use one myself, and I can tell you it’s a great product.

M: OK. I know it’s more than I wanted to pay, but you’ve talked me into buying it.

W: Well, how would you like to pay for it? By cheque or in cash?

M: Well, here’s my credit card.

W: Fine, and can I see your boarding pass, please?

M: Eh, my boarding pass … I remember I placed it in my bag with my ID card and my passport … Oh, here it is.

data.sub:
[{"id":10952,"main_id":61273,"questions":1,"subject":"What time will the horses be ready?","answer":"B. At 10:00 a.m.","answer_a":"A. At 11:30 a.m.","answer_b":"B. At 10:00 a.m.","answer_c":"C. At 8:30 a.m.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Well, thank you for inviting me here today to talk to you about the riding and holiday centre I run.

Let me tell you about a normal day’s activities. You’ll probably be pleased to know we don’t make you get up too early! We have our breakfast at 8:30. After that, we begin at 10 o’clock by getting the horses ready. You need to make sure you have the right equipment before the ride begins at about 11:30.

For the first few miles we go quite slowly, breaking for about an hour at midday, near a beach or a lake where you can swim or sunbathe. At about 1:00 p.m., we have packed lunch together. We arrive back at the Centre at about 4:00 p.m.

Everyone has to wear a hard hat and these are available free of charge at the Centre. Sports shoes are no good for riding, I’m afraid. Strong shoes or boots with a small heel are best. Warm clothes such as jeans and sweaters, some swimwear and a small shoulder bag for carrying a packed lunch are useful.

And now for the price. Well, a four-day holiday is £292 per person and that includes the riding and the equipment. The cost of food and hotel rooms is not included.

M: What do you do?

W: I’m a new student here. How about you?

M: Me too.

W: Really, so we’re both new. Where are you from?

M: Actually, I’m from Paris, but I live in New York now. How about you?

W: Oh, I’m from London.

M: Do you have many classes this term?

W: I have five, er, no four, on Monday, Wednesday, Thursday and Friday. How about you?

M: I have three classes, on Monday, Tuesday and Friday.

W: So what classes do you have?

M: English, Chemistry and French.

W: Really? When do you have French?

M: At eleven. It’s with Ms. Turner.

W: Hey, me too.

M: Betty, where are you?

W: Sh! Quiet! Lisa is sleeping. I’m here in the kitchen. I’m preparing dinner.

M: You know what? I’ve got a raise in salary, Betty! Mr. Smith has been watching my work, and he thinks I should get a raise in salary.

It always has different tasks.","answer_b":"B. It includes much research.","answer_c":"C. Its salary is satisfactory.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: So what do you enjoy most about your present job?

M: I’ve learnt a lot working with the sales and marketing team. I like it — you know, it’s not the same task day after day. The people in the team are great. I enjoy satisfaction — when we meet our goals, I mean.

W: And what about the daily task, the administration and so on?

M: Many people may think they’re boring. But it’s not a problem for me. I think it’s necessary to do the daily work well too.

W: Why would you like to work here?

M: The job looks very challenging — some of the areas are similar to what I do now, but with more responsibility. Then, in a big company like this, I think I’ll have more chances to learn new things. And I hope I can manage my team in a few years’ time.

W: What qualities do you bring to this position?

M: I’m creative and energetic. Obviously I don’t know everything about your products, but I do have a few ideas about the marketing possibilities.

W: And what would you say are your weak points?

M: I suppose I can be impatient, sometimes.

W: Hmm …

To have a good singing voice.","answer_c":"C. To teach more children to sing.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: OK, I’m going to talk about one of my wishes. I think everybody has one or two things they wish they could change about themselves and for me I really wish I could sing. Unfortunately I have a terrible voice.

I cannot sing at all, and in Japan, this is very embarrassing because Japanese people love to go to Karaoke. And Karaoke is when you go with a few friends to a place, a Karaoke bar, I guess, or a centre, you get a small room and inside the room there are songs on the TV. You can choose what songs to watch and then one person sings the song. Everyone listens and it’s very popular in Japan and it’s a lot of fun but I feel really embarrassed because I can’t sing and everybody always says, “Oh, no, it’s OK. Don’t worry.” But after I sing, everybody doesn’t want me to sing anymore.

It’s also very hard for me because I love teaching children and when I teach children I need to teach songs. Songs are very important for children when they’re little. I think the reason I cannot sing is because unfortunately in my country, the United States, we don’t sing as children and I really would like this to change. So yeah, I really wish I could sing although I don’t think that it’s ever going to be a reality.

He visited an old friend.","answer_b":"B. He tasted some Italian food.","answer_c":"C. He found new science titles.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: You’ve just come back from the Turin Book Fair. How did it go?

M: The fair was quite a success. Lots of people were interested in the new science titles that we’ve published. And I met up with an old friend. And I enjoyed Italian food there in a restaurant.

W: Has this been a good year for you?

M: Yes, we’ve done really well in Western Europe — we’ve sold more books than ever before. And we’ve started selling books in countries in Eastern Europe as well — for example, in Poland and Hungary. Poland is doing well. The demand for our books has been almost as high as in Spain and Portugal.

W: So what’s next then? I’m sure you’ve got something new planned.

M: Well, we’re going to move the actual printing to Slovakia. We found a printing company there. They’re going to take over about 80% of our book printing next year. 

W: Really? I’ve just been to Slovakia.

M: Well, I’m going to be there next month. I’m going to have a discussion with the printers. After that, I’m going to take a few days’ holiday.

M: Yes, we’ve done really well in Western Europe — we’ve sold more books than ever before. And we’ve started selling books in countries in Eastern Europe as well — for example, in Poland and Hungary. Poland is doing well. The demand for our books has been almost as high as in Spain and Portugal.

W: So what’s next then? I’m sure you’ve got something new planned.

M: Well, we’re going to move the actual printing to Slovakia. We found a printing company there. They’re going to take over about 80% of our book printing next year. 

W: Really? I’ve just been to Slovakia.

M: Well, I’m going to be there next month. I’m going to have a discussion with the printers. After that, I’m going to take a few days’ holiday.

[{"id":11103,"main_id":61329,"questions":1,"subject":"What does the speaker think is important for his job?","answer":"A. Good teamwork.","answer_a":"A. Good teamwork.","answer_b":"B. Job-related tests.","answer_c":"C. Brilliant talent.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: I always wanted to be a fireman. To be accepted, you have to pass a number of job-related tests, both written and practical, some of which are physical and others have more to do with your talent for the work. Above all, you’re working as part of a group when you rely on each other to do the job well. And that is important for my work. Also, I find that no two days are the same and this keeps my interest high. Our work varies greatly, from animal rescues to road traffic accidents, just about every emergency situation you could think of. The only thing that I’m dissatisfied with my job at present would have to be the pay. I’ve been a firefighter since I was 18, which is 26 years now, and I earn £21,000. This is less than the starting salary of a police officer. Luckily, there’re very good holiday arrangements, and excellent retirement benefits. And you might expect, health care service is very good and we all take personal fitness extremely seriously, so there are gyms and a lot of other sports equipment on hand in most stations. If you’re good at sports, the service will help you be as good as you can be.

[{"id":11169,"main_id":61366,"questions":1,"subject":"What is the most probable relationship between the speakers?","answer":"B. Husband and wife.","answer_a":"A. Neighbours.","answer_b":"B. Husband and wife.","answer_c":"C. Colleagues.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Darling. I’ve been thinking. You know Jane and Robert who just moved in next door, have just had a baby girl. I really think we ought to get them some sort of present.

M: You’re right. Have you got anything in mind?

W: Why don’t we get the baby a nice little dress? I was in “Mothercare” the other day and they had some lovely ones in there.

M: A dress? I expect they’ve received loads of clothes for the baby. What about a toy? Something the baby can play with.

W: New-born babies don’t play with toys, darling. They just sleep, eat and cry! Maybe we should get Jane and Robert something useful for the baby.

M: Yes. Useful … and boring!

W: Boring? Just because something’s useful, doesn’t mean it has to be boring!

M: Well, I still think a toy would be better. We could get her one of those things you put on the child’s bed that plays music and goes around in circles.

W: Oh yes. You mean a wind bell? Yes, that’s a good idea. Why don’t we go and see if we can find one this afternoon?

M: All right.

[{"id":11176,"main_id":61370,"questions":1,"subject":"What kind of talk is the speaker giving?","answer":"B. A recorded phone message.","answer_a":"A. An ad on the theatre.","answer_b":"B. A recorded phone message.","answer_c":"C. A radio announcement.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: This is the Odeon Theatre box office. We’re closed right now, but if you require further information, please hold the line. 

The week running from the 19th to the 24th of February is full of interesting, exciting things to see. On Tuesday the 19th, there is a concert of guitar music given by Jose Fernando Martinez. This world-famous Spanish guitarist will play a group of music from classical to jazz.

If it’s Shakespeare plays you are after, then Wednesday the 20th is the night for you. The Stratford Shakespeare Company, who have been performing here over the last two years with great success are putting on Macbeth. So don’t miss it.

For those of you who prefer comedy, we’ll have the comedian Bob Connelly. Mr. Connelly always has some interesting guests to interview. We can make sure that he’ll certainly give you a laugh. That’s on Thursday the 21st.

A famous ballet The Lime Light is on the 22nd. The times have changed slightly and it will now start 15 minutes later, at 8:45 instead of 8:30 p.m.

On Sunday there’s a musical, The Snowman. Your children will love it. There’s a 50% discount for children.

For more information send for our weekly programme or visit the box office. Bookings can be made in person or by telephoning our bookings line.

W: This is the Odeon Theatre box office. We’re closed right now, but if you require further information, please hold the line. 

The week running from the 19th to the 24th of February is full of interesting, exciting things to see. On Tuesday the 19th, there is a concert of guitar music given by Jose Fernando Martinez. This world-famous Spanish guitarist will play a group of music from classical to jazz.

If it’s Shakespeare plays you are after, then Wednesday the 20th is the night for you. The Stratford Shakespeare Company, who have been performing here over the last two years with great success are putting on Macbeth. So don’t miss it.

For those of you who prefer comedy, we’ll have the comedian Bob Connelly. Mr. Connelly always has some interesting guests to interview. We can make sure that he’ll certainly give you a laugh. That’s on Thursday the 21st.

On Sunday there’s a musical, The Snowman. Your children will love it. There’s a 50% discount for children.

To show the importance of clothing.","answer_b":"B. To give some tips on how to impress the employer.","answer_c":"C. To tell the listeners how first impressions are formed.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Whether you’re in the process of job hunting or just settling into your first job, the following steps are a must if you want yourself to be a good “ready for the world of work” young person. The first thing to recognize is that appearance is important. You will be judged by your employers in the first five seconds of meeting them and 93% of the overall impression you’ll make will be based on the way you package yourself. First, clothes: in general, suits are a must. But depending on whether the company has a casual dress culture or a more formal one, dress accordingly. Men, go for dark grey. Accompany it with a colored shirt and a tie. Women should find a suit to match their character. Try a little color — perhaps a light green. Forget about borrowing a suit. Even if it’s of high quality, it probably won’t fit you and will make you uncomfortable. Then you’ll give off your bad feelings. Body language is really important, too. Always smile; it shows confidence. A good handshake scores well, so test yours on your friends before you go to an interview.

W: Welcome to HD Cinema. What can I do for you?

M: Well ... I wonder when Kung Fu Panda III is showing.

W: There are five shows today, one at noon, and then 2 p.m., 5 p.m., 8 p.m., and 11 p.m. At the weekend, besides these five shows, there is another show at midnight.

M: OK, I’d like six tickets for the 11 p.m. show tonight. 

W: Let me see. Oh, I’m sorry, but there are only three tickets left. How about the 8 p.m. one? There are still 10 tickets left for that show.

M: But I have a friend who won’t get off work until 8 p.m. Is there any way that we could book tickets for tomorrow?

W: Of course. What time would you like for tomorrow?

M: Tomorrow is Saturday, so I think there might be more people who want to see the movie. How many tickets can I buy at a time?

W: The limit for advanced tickets is ten.

M: OK, I’ll have 10 tickets for the midnight show tomorrow.

W: OK.

[{"id":11249,"main_id":61420,"questions":1,"subject":"When will the Japanese space holiday centre probably be ready?","answer":"A. In 2017.","answer_a":"A. In 2017.","answer_b":"B. In 2019.","answer_c":"C. In 2020.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: The World Tourism Organization says that space will soon be a popular place to go on holiday — possibly by 2020. One Japanese company is getting ready. They are planning a space holiday centre. It will look like a bicycle wheel and have a hotel for 100 people and a theme park. It will travel round the Earth at a height of 300 km. The centre will likely be ready in 2017. The company chairman says he thinks that flying to the centre will probably be quicker than flying from Hong Kong to Singapore. When they are on board the centre, the tourists will take short trips to the moon or go for walks in space. But what about the cost? Well, the company believes that people will be happy to pay about 100,000 dollars for a trip but they think that as more people want to go, the trip will become much cheaper.

An American hotel group is also thinking of building a hotel, called the Lunar Hotel. It’ll probably be ready by 2019. This will be on the moon. Most of the hotel will be under the ground so it won’t become too hot or too cold. The rooms will look just like they do on Earth with curtains, carpets, plants and they will have wall-to-wall television. The guests will eat normal food for lunch. The cooks will just push a button to mix dried food with water to become an instant meal! There will be little or no dirt and there won’t be much water, so the hotel won’t wash the towels or sheets — it will throw them away!

[{"id":11285,"main_id":61450,"questions":1,"subject":"What does the man do?","answer":"B. A writer.","answer_a":"A. An actor.","answer_b":"B. A writer.","answer_c":"C. A host.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Good evening and welcome to tonight’s edition of Legendary Lives. Our subject this evening is James Dean. Edward Murray is the author of a new biography of Dean. So Edward, tell us what you know about Dean’s early life.

M: He was born in Indiana in 1931, but his parents moved to California when he was five. He wasn’t there long though because his mother passed away just four years later. Dean’s father sent him back to Indiana after that to live with his aunt.

W: So how did he get into acting?

M: Well, first he acted in plays at high school, then he went to college in California where he got into acting officially. In 1951 he moved to New York to do more stage acting.

W: Then when did he start movies?

M: In 1955. His first starring role was in East of Eden. The movie that really made him famous was Rebel Without a Cause. That was about teenagers who felt like they didn’t fit into society. Dean died in a car crash in California.

","image_url":"","spell_word":""},{"id":11286,"main_id":61450,"questions":1,"subject":"Why did Dean move back to Indiana when he was young?","answer":"A. His mother died.","answer_a":"A. W: Good evening and welcome to tonight’s edition of Legendary Lives. Our subject this evening is James Dean. Edward Murray is the author of a new biography of Dean. So Edward, tell us what you know about Dean’s early life.

M: He was born in Indiana in 1931, but his parents moved to California when he was five. He wasn’t there long though because his mother passed away just four years later. Dean’s father sent him back to Indiana after that to live with his aunt.

W: So how did he get into acting?

[{"id":11293,"main_id":61454,"questions":1,"subject":"When was Haybridge built?","answer":"A. In the 15th century.","answer_a":"A. In the 15th century.","answer_b":"B. In the 16th century.","answer_c":"C. In the 17th century.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Welcome to Haybridge Hall. I’d like to introduce the general history of the house to you.

Haybridge Hall was constructed at the end of the 15th century and was originally called Hawken Hall after the first family who owned it. The Hawken family only managed to hold onto this house for around a decade before they had to sell it and the name Haybridge was used by the family who bought it. The Yardley family owned Haybridge for some 200 years and turned the surrounding area into farmland where various crops were grown.

The Yardley family left Haybridge in 1722 and the place was left empty for about sixty years.

The famous local author William Hoaten bought Haybridge in 1784 and spent three years and a large amount of money repairing it. But the amount of the land had been greatly reduced. The Hoaten family stayed at Haybridge until the beginning of the Second World War when the British Army took it over. After the war, the surviving members of the Hoaten family decided it would be too costly to move back into Haybridge Hall and so Haybridge came to be owned by English Heritage.

English Heritage made a big repair operation in the 1970’s, costing over ten million dollars. The aim was to return Haybridge Hall to something of its glory days in the 17th century. 

Haybridge Hall remains to this day one of the finest examples of British architecture and the furnishing within gives a good idea of what country life was like three to four centuries ago in this country.

That’s all from me. Now you can walk around Haybridge Hall.

[{"id":11346,"main_id":61488,"questions":1,"subject":"Which computer course dissatisfies Mrs. Lewis?","answer":"C. The one on April 26th.","answer_a":"A. The one on April 24th.","answer_b":"B. The one on April 25th.","answer_c":"C. The one on April 26th.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Hello, Fred. Sorry to bother you, but I’ve just received a letter from Mrs. Lewis here. She isn’t happy and I need to reply as soon as possible.

M: Really? What’s the problem?

W: Well, she’s referring to a computer course on the 25th of April. Two people from her company were on the course.

M: I think you mean on the 26th actually. The 25th was a Sunday.

W: Oh, OK. Anyway, you know about it?

M: Well, I wasn’t here. I was supposed to be but I had to take the day off work because of my son — he was sick. My wife was away on vacation so as a result I called early to see if we could get a replacement trainer. Anyway, we did and the trainer was a little late. However, he’s good. I know his work. And we added the lost time on to the end of class. Is that what they’re not satisfied about?

W: Well, that’s one thing. I didn’t know you added the time back on. That’s useful to know. And it’s also because of a room change or something.

M: Well, I had told them the course was full and we could only take one of their people, but they still sent two. So rather than sending one of them home we were able to switch training rooms and deal with it.

W: So that sounds like their fault. OK. That’s all I need to know. I’m sure I can sort it out.

[{"id":11350,"main_id":61491,"questions":1,"subject":"How far does Coober Pedy lie from south of Alice Springs?","answer":"A. 690 kilometres.","answer_a":"A. 690 kilometres.","answer_b":"B. 860 kilometres.","answer_c":"C. 960 kilometres.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: Good afternoon. In this class we’re talking about Coober Pedy, the Australia desert town. It lies 860 kilometres north of Adelaide and 690 south of Alice Springs. The extreme climate and almost total lack of water made it a highly unlikely place for humans to live, but that all started to change in 1915 with the discovery of the precious stones, which seem to change colour according to their surroundings.

Settlements were founded following the First World War, when Australian soldiers returning from the battlefields of France brought with them the techniques of living below ground. During the period of the 1920s and 30s, the town was so poor that many explorers left. But the town became active again in the late 1940s. Some people from Europe arrived in large numbers after the Second World War. 

It must be remembered how tough conditions were. Daytime summer temperatures reached well over 50 degrees Centigrade, and winter nights were bitterly cold. To deal with this, more and more people began living in underground houses, where the temperature remains at a comfortable 25 degrees all year round. 

As years go by, the homes have become bigger. There are now also some hotels for tourists. They come from all over the world just to see this unusual town. Coober Pedy is probably best known for its unique style of underground living.

W: Good afternoon. In this class we’re talking about Coober Pedy, the Australia desert town. It lies 860 kilometres north of Adelaide and 690 south of Alice Springs. The extreme climate and almost total lack of water made it a highly unlikely place for humans to live, but that all started to change in 1915 with the discovery of the precious stones, which seem to change colour according to their surroundings.

Settlements were founded following the First World War, when Australian soldiers returning from the battlefields of France brought with them the techniques of living below ground. During the period of the 1920s and 30s, the town was so poor that many explorers left. But the town became active again in the late 1940s. Some people from Europe arrived in large numbers after the Second World War. 

It must be remembered how tough conditions were. Daytime summer temperatures reached well over 50 degrees Centigrade, and winter nights were bitterly cold. To deal with this, more and more people began living in underground houses, where the temperature remains at a comfortable 25 degrees all year round. 

As years go by, the homes have become bigger. There are now also some hotels for tourists. They come from all over the world just to see this unusual town. Coober Pedy is probably best known for its unique style of underground living.

[{"id":11414,"main_id":61523,"questions":1,"subject":"How did the speaker book the hotel room?","answer":"A. Over the phone.","answer_a":"A. Over the phone.","answer_b":"B. Through a friend.","answer_c":"C. On the website.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: I took my first trip to Ogunquit this past week with a great friend. I decided on the Admiral’s Inn. After seeing a few pictures on their website, my heart was set on a room with an outdoor set — two chairs and a small table. Nothing is better than waking up and enjoying the first cup of coffee outdoors. Instead of booking through the website, I called the hotel directly to confirm that I got one of the rooms with an outdoor set, and the gentleman on the other end was as pleasant as could be. He arranged things exactly as what I hoped.

On travel day, we hit more traffic than expected. We called to let the hotel know that we would be a late check-in, and they were fine with it, stating that someone would be at the front desk until at least midnight. We drove straight through and made it by 11:30 p.m. Marty at the front counter was fantastic when we arrived. He gave us an overview of the town, what to see, what to do, how to get around. 

The hotel itself was perfect for us. The room was really spacious. There was a small mini fridge that worked well. The bathroom was clean and also spacious. My only real dissatisfaction with the room is that the main window has thick curtains which work wonderfully, but there’s no privacy curtains. If you want any natural light in the room, you become completely exposed to anyone walking by. A soft white curtain added under the current thick curtains would be perfect.

M: Hello, this is George Damon. Our company will be having a sales meeting in January. And we need to book a room for about 200 people. Does your hotel have something that can accommodate that number?

W: Yes, sir. We have a couple of rooms for groups of that size.

M: Good. We’ll need chairs, a stage and a projection screen.

W: Then I would suggest Room 13. 

M: Well, I don’t like the room number. 

W: Oh, sorry sir. Room 19 and Room 26 are also available.

M: I prefer something ending with 9.

W: I see. I’ll reserve that for you right now.

M: Do you know when the repairman will be here to fix the air conditioner? He was supposed to be here an hour ago.

W: I just called to speak to someone at his office. They apologized and said that repairman was having difficulty finding our clinic. They showed him the way and he should be here a little later.

M: I hope he gets here soon because it’s supposed to be really hot today. If we don’t get the air conditioner repaired by noon, we’d better cancel all of our patient appointments today and reschedule them.

[{"id":11427,"main_id":61536,"questions":1,"subject":"What are the speakers discussing?","answer":"A. What to do for a project.","answer_a":"A. What to do for a project.","answer_b":"B. When to draw a picture.","answer_c":"C. How to be a good artist.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

W: What are you going to do for the project?

M: I don’t know. I was hoping you could help me think of something.

W: Well, you’re such a good artist, you could talk about watercolor while you’re doing one in front of the class.

M: Maybe, but what if I make a mistake in front of everyone?

W: Come on, you’re really talented. Besides, you wouldn’t have to do much preparation beforehand.

M: True. 

W: Or, how about this? You could bring in a photo, a pencil drawing, and a watercolor of the same subject. Something simple so it wouldn’t take so much time to do, like a flower. Then you could show the advantages and disadvantages of working with different materials.

M: I could do that ahead of time.

W: You could, but remember, it would take a lot more time.

M: Sure, thanks.

data.sub:
[{"id":11430,"main_id":61537,"questions":1,"subject":"Where does Susan live now?","answer":"A. In Italy.","answer_a":"A. In Italy.","answer_b":"B. In England.","answer_c":"C. In America.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Hello, and welcome to our program, “Working Abroad”. Our guest this evening is a Londoner, who lives and works in Italy. Her name’s Susan Hill. Susan, welcome to the program. You live in Florence. How long have you been living there?

W: Since 1982. But when I went there in 1982, I planned to stay for only 6 months.

M: Why did you change your mind?

W: Well, soon after I arrived in Florence, I got a job with one of Italy’s top companies, Ferragamo. So, I decided to stay.

M: How lucky! Do you still work for Ferragamo?

W: No. I left there in 1988. I’ve been a free designer since then. I’ve designed for some Italian companies as well as two American companies. And in the last five years, I’ve also been designing for the British company, Burberry.

M: What have you been designing for them?

W: Mostly handbags and sometimes shoes and leather jackets.

M: How’s your industry changed since 1982?

W: It’s become a lot more competitive because the quality of products from other countries has improved a lot. But Italian quality and design is still world-famous.

M: Well, thank you for talking to us, Susan.

[{"id":11434,"main_id":61538,"questions":1,"subject":"When will the ferry leave for Boulogne?","answer":"B. At 9:05.","answer_a":"A. At 9:00.","answer_b":"B. At 9:05.","answer_c":"C. At 11:05.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Hello, ladies and gentlemen, welcome aboard your Sea-link ferry from Folkestone to Boulogne and wish you a pleasant trip with us. Now it’s 9 a.m. and we are due to leave Folkestone in five minutes and a journey to Boulogne will take about two hours. Sun and a temperature of 30 degrees are reported on the French coast, so we should have a calm crossing. For your convenience on the journey, we’d like to point out what we provide for you on board. There’s a bar serving sandwiches and hot and cold drinks in the front of Floor A. There is also a restaurant serving hot meals on Floor B. If you need to change money or cash travelers’ checks, we have a bank on board. You can find the bank on Floor C. Between the ship’s office and the duty free shop, toilets are on Floor B at the back of the ship and on Floor A next to the bar. For the children, there’s a games room on Floor C. Here children can find a variety of electronic games. Passengers are reminded that the relaxing room on Floor B is only for passengers traveling with cars and that there is another relaxing room on Floor C in the front of the ship for passengers traveling without cars. Finally, ladies and gentlemen, we’d like to wish you a pleasant journey and hope that you’ll travel with us again in the near future.
